knowledge.heading: Clinical Empathy
knowledge.description:
The narrative uses third-person limited point of view.

But it's filtered specifically through a medical perspective — we see events through the lens of clinical understanding.

This combines two approaches:
• Objective stance: clinical, factual observations
• Compassionate stance: empathetic, caring tone

The result is therapeutic distance.

Ask yourself: Why would an author want this kind of distance?

The medical filter creates enough emotional space between reader and trauma — we're not overwhelmed by raw pain.

This distance paradoxically enables deeper understanding.

When we're not drowning in emotion, we can examine the trauma more clearly and comprehensively.
knowledge.reader_effect:
Readers experience psychological wounds in two distinct ways:
• Clinical observation — watching from the outside, like a doctor studying symptoms
• Intimate consciousness — feeling from the inside, sharing the character's inner world

This dual perspective creates a powerful combination:
• Intellectual comprehension — we understand what is happening and why
• Emotional resonance — we feel the impact on a personal level

Ask yourself: Why does the author give us both viewpoints? 

The pairing means we don't just analyze the psychological damage — we also experience its emotional weight.

quick_reference.voice: Third person limited primarily through Rivers' perspective with occasional shifts to other characters
quick_reference.tone: Clinical yet empathetic, exploring psychological trauma with medical precision and human compassion

worked_example.effect:
Readers encounter psychological wounds in two distinct ways:

• Clinical observation — watching from the outside, like a doctor studying symptoms
• Intimate consciousness — experiencing from within the character's mind

This dual approach creates a powerful combination:

The clinical perspective gives us intellectual comprehension — we understand what's happening and why.

The intimate perspective gives us emotional resonance — we feel the impact alongside the character.

Ask yourself: Why would an author want both? The pairing means readers don't just analyse the psychological damage — they experience it viscerally while maintaining enough distance to reflect on its meaning.
